channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Davos Convenes, Deference to Trump Has Replaced Everything
item.description: The traditional rhetoric of the World Economic Forum centered on global integration, climate change and international cooperation. Not anymore.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: Attendees at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last year.

item.title: One Month Later, CBS Airs Postponed ‘60 Minutes’ Report With Few Changes
item.description: A 13-minute segment about Venezuelan men deported by the Trump administration had been pulled at the last minute by CBS News’s editor in chief, Bari Weiss.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The report featured the stories of Venezuelan men deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador.

item.title: China’s Birthrate Plunges to Lowest Level Since 1949
item.description: China’s population fell for a fourth straight year and its birthrate tumbled as policymakers failed to slow a demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Despite sweeping efforts to boost births, China’s population has shrunk and aged for a fourth straight year as deaths again outnumbered births.

item.title: Real Estate Crash Weighs on China’s Economic Growth
item.description: Falling apartment prices have erased the savings of millions of Chinese households, but exports lifted the economy to 5 percent growth last year.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: China is still grappling with a property market crash that began four years ago, after many years of overbuilding.

item.title: Joe Montgomery, Who Made Bicycles Lighter, Dies at 86
item.description: A founder of Cannondale, he was among the first in the U.S. to mass-produce bikes frames out of large-diameter aluminum tubes, replacing heavier steel.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Top Editor at Axel Springer Is Ousted After Workplace Investigation
item.description: Jan Philipp Burgard was one of Axel Springer’s most prominent editors, overseeing its influential German broadsheet Welt.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Hannes P Albert/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jan Philipp Burgard in Berlin in June. He had said in a social media post that he had decided to resign after experiencing “a serious physical incident” on a flight back from vacation.

item.title: Trump’s Campaign Manager Resolves Daily Beast Defamation Suit
item.description: As part of the settlement, The Daily Beast was not required to apologize or issue any payment to Chris LaCivita, who sued the outlet last year.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chris LaCivita, a former campaign manager for President Trump, at a session of Congress in March for an address by Mr. Trump.

item.title: How to Prevent Aging Parents and Relatives from Making Financial Mistakes
item.description: Getting family members to listen to you when you think they are headed down a dangerous financial path can be difficult. But there are preventive steps you can take.
item.dc:creator: Paulette Perhach
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2024, Rianka Dorsainvil’s mother came to her with a check that looked legitimate. It turned out to be part of a common check fraud scam.

item.title: The Man Delivering FedEx Into the Age of Drones, Robots and A.I.
item.description: Raj Subramaniam took over three years ago from FedEx’s founder, who ran the company for nearly 50 years. Since then, technology, tariffs and other disruptions have “fundamentally shifted” patterns of global trade.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Whitten Sabbatini for The New York Times
item.media:description: FedEx, which handles more than 17 million packages per day, is the “heartbeat of the industrial economy,” Mr. Subramaniam said.

item.title: At Davos, Global Leaders Gather to Ponder the Future of a Messy World
item.description: At its 56th annual meeting in Davos, the World Economic Forum will wrestle with war, economics, artificial intelligence and other pressing issues.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.category: Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of Iranians have taken to the streets during the latest uprising, including an anti-government protest in Tehran.

item.title: Can Davos Help Protect the Planet?
item.description: The World Economic Forum, which takes place in Switzerland, aims to meet at least some of the goals its leaders set for the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora
item.media:description: The town of Davos, Switzerland, site of the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. Over the years, the event’s organizers have been working to reduce the environmental impact of the meeting.

item.title: No One’s Buying? Maybe Consumers Are Just ‘Choiceful,’ Executives Say.
item.description: A new way to characterize unenthusiastic consumers has overtaken earnings calls.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley

item.title: White House Warns CBS: Air Trump Interview in Full, or ‘We’ll Sue’
item.description: In previously unreported remarks, the White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told CBS News that Mr. Trump would “sue” the news outlet if it did not air an interview unedited.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, at a briefing at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: National Anger Spills Into Target Stores, Again
item.description: Videos of immigration officers dragging an employee out of a store near Minneapolis, the retailer’s hometown, set off renewed political debate after years of boycotts.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Jacey Fortin and Sheila M. Eldred
item.media:description: Gregory Bovino, center, a Border Patrol official, at a Target store in St. Paul, Minn., this month. Last week, agents detained two employees at a Target in Richfield, Minn.

item.title: Trump Announces New Tariffs on Some European Countries in Greenland Standoff
item.description: The president escalated his drive to take charge of the Danish territory, targeting Denmark and seven other European countries with a 10 percent rate.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said the new tariff would increase to 25 percent on June 1 if his demands were not met.

item.title: Big Oil’s Complicated Calculus for Investing in Venezuela
item.description: The industry has long prioritized projects with quick and reliable payback. Trump is pushing for a return to risk.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:description: A mural in Caracas depicts an oil pumpjack on a Venezuelan flag.

item.title: At Least $110,000 Worth of Pokémon Cards Stolen From New York Store
item.description: The robbery at the Poké Court on Wednesday was the latest in a string of thefts of high-value Pokémon trading cards.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

item.title: Tech Firms Are Persuading Retailers to Put A.I. Everywhere
item.description: Stores of all kinds are using artificial intelligence to sell everything from luxury handbags to hay for horses.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin and Sophia June
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:description: John Furner, incoming chief executive of Walmart, left, and Sundar Pichai, Google’s leader, said at a conference in New York City this week that the two companies would use artificial intelligence to change how all businesses sold their products.

item.title: ‘Punched in the Face’ by a Rail Disaster, an Ohio Town Fights Its Way Back
item.description: Residents and officials are still trying to revitalize East Palestine nearly three years after a derailment and chemical burn.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis and Ross Mantle
item.media:credit: Ross Mantle for The New York Times

item.title: As Office Rents Rise, Doctors Get Creative
item.description: Physicians with independent practices are having to cobble together unconventional office arrangements at a time of rising costs and consolidation in the medical field.
item.dc:creator: Jane Margolies
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Zarui Chopuryan, an aesthetic medicine provider, working with a patient in her office in New York, N.Y.

item.title: Black Women Turn to One Another as Their Career Paths Suddenly Recede
item.description: Black female professionals have seen a steep drop in employment over the last year. They are turning to each other for pep talks and résumé advice.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nneka Obiekwe started a chat group for Black women professionals looking for work. Within 24 hours, 500 people had joined.

item.title: F.A.A. Urges ‘Caution’ Over Oceans in Latin America, Warning of Military Activity
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration released seven advisories warning pilots to stay away from parts of the Pacific Ocean near Mexico, Colombia, Ecuador and Panama.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An American F-35 fighter jet taking off from an airport in Puerto Rico in December.

item.title: Edison Files Claims Against Los Angeles County and Others on Eaton Fire
item.description: Southern California Edison said its equipment most likely started the Eaton fire but asserted that government agencies and other businesses shared liability for the devastation.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eaton fire killed 19 people and destroyed more than 9,400 buildings in Southern California.

item.title: WestJet Backpedals on Economy Seats That Don’t Recline
item.description: WestJet, Canada’s second-largest carrier, backpedaled on a new seating plan after videos of crammed travelers went viral on social media.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: WestJet had narrowed the distance between one row of seats and the next to 28 inches from about 30 inches.

item.title: Trump and States Aim to Stop A.I. From Inflating Energy Bills
item.description: Demand from centers that power artificial intelligence has driven up electricity bills, frustrating consumers.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nationwide spike in electricity costs is being driven by the construction of data centers that power artificial intelligence.

item.title: Trump Praises Hassett, but Casts Doubt on Making Him Fed Chair
item.description: The blowback set off by the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the central bank, has shaken up the race to replace him.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.media:description: Kevin A. Hassett serves as the director of the White House National Economic Council.

item.title: Powell, an Unlikely Foil, Takes On Trump
item.description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, this week tapped a groundswell of support that has been years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:description: The overwhelming defense of Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, is the product of something President Trump may have underestimated: Mr. Powell’s popularity.

item.title: Your Tax Refund Could Be Taken if You’ve Defaulted on Student Loans: What to Know
item.description: The Education Department reversed course and announced on Friday that it would delay aggressive efforts to collect what was owed on student loans.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Michael Saylor’s Creative Bitcoin Strategy Isn’t Working
item.description: Michael Saylor’s financial alchemy thrust an ordinary software company, Strategy, into the center of the crypto frenzy. It all worked spectacularly, until now.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland

item.title: What’s Next for Cuba, Now That Its Main Oil Supplier Is Gone?
item.description: The Soviet Union was Cuba’s benefactor for decades. Venezuela took up the slack, and Mexico has supplied “humanitarian aid.” But the world is changing rapidly, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:description: A street in Havana. Cuba is reported to have less than two months of imported oil on hand.

item.title: Larry Fink, the New Mayor of Davos
item.description: Larry Fink, BlackRock’s chief executive, led an effort to elevate the World Economic Forum next week, the first without the event’s founder, Klaus Schwab.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Larry Fink, C.E.O. of BlackRock, has become a force in reshaping the agenda and participant list for the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Ted Sarandos Says Critics Just Misunderstand Netflix
item.description: The company’s co-chief executive sat down for an extensive interview for the first time since announcing plans to buy Warner Bros. Discovery’s film and TV business.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re going to be the buyer who keeps Warner Bros. running, releasing movies in theaters the way they always have,” said Ted Sarandos of Netflix, talking about the company’s deal for Warner Bros. Discovery’s movie and TV business.

item.title: Stock Investors’ Strategy for 2026: ‘Don’t Fight the White House’
item.description: From oil drillers to credit card companies, President Trump has been a market mover this year.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Battles Over Truth Rage Online Amid Iran’s Internet Blackout
item.description: The shutdown of online discourse within Iran has allowed both the government and its critics to flood social media outside the country with disinformation campaigns and fake images.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: A frame grab from footage circulating on social media showing protesters dancing and cheering in Tehran last week.

item.title: Uber’s Quest to Crack Japan Leads Through a Rural Hot-Springs Town
item.description: The ride-hailing giant’s chief executive has made a bet on how it can finally grab a bigger piece of one of the world’s largest taxi markets.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis

item.title: Taiwan Reaches Trade Deal With Trump and Pledges More U.S. Chip Factories
item.description: The Trump administration agreed to lower tariffs on Taiwanese goods, while Taiwan said it would invest more in U.S. manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Amy Chang Chien and Xinyun Wu
item.media:description: Taiwan manufactures most of the world’s advanced semiconductors.

item.title: How Activists in Iran Are Using Starlink to Stay Online
item.description: Activists spent years preparing for a communications blackout in Iran, smuggling in Starlink satellite internet systems and making digital shutdowns harder for the authorities to enforce.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Middle East Images/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Starlink receiver atop a house in Kurdistan, Iran, in 2023. About 50,000 Starlink terminals are now in the country, according to digital activists.

item.title: Kathleen Kennedy, Lucasfilm President and ‘Star Wars’ Boss, Steps Down
item.description: Kathleen Kennedy stepped down as Lucasfilm’s president and returned to producing. Two studio veterans took over.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: Kathleen Kennedy and Dave Filoni at a “Star Wars” fan convention in Japan in April.

item.title: Italian Court Closes Fraud Case Against Influencer Chiara Ferragni
item.description: A judge dropped a case against Chiara Ferragni tied to her promotion of a Christmas pandoro marketed as supporting cancer treatment.
item.dc:creator: Josephine de La Bruyère and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Chiara Ferragni arriving at the Milan Courthouse on Wednesday. A judge dismissed the fraud case against the influencer, but prosecutors could still consider an appeal.

item.title: Leonard D. Jacoby, 83, Dies; Brought Legal Services to the Masses
item.description: He and Steven Z. Meyers opened their first low-cost legal clinic in 1972. Within a decade, they had revolutionized the legal industry, and Jacoby & Meyers had become a widely known brand.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: State and Federal Lawmakers Want Data Centers to Pay More for Energy
item.description: Despite many proposals, there is little consensus among governors, lawmakers and tech executives about exactly how much the companies behind data centers should pay for electricity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: A data center built by OpenAI and Oracle in Abilene, Texas.

item.title: Big Plan for Fannie and Freddie I.P.O. in Flux as Trump Pushes Affordability
item.description: Six months after President Trump told Wall Street banks to prepare a swift stock offering, there is no firm plan for how to take the giant mortgage firms public.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Lauren Hirsch
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were taken over by the federal government during the 2008 financial crisis, but their status after a planned I.P.O. remains unclear.

item.title: Trump Outlines Health Care Proposals as Prices and Premiums Rise
item.description: The long-awaited plan would leave much to Congress and calls for payments to health savings accounts rather than insurance subsidies, among other broad proposals.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Rebecca Robbins, Margot Sanger-Katz and Michael Gold
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:description: President Trump released a video promoting what he calls “the great health care plan.”

item.title: Coinbase, the Biggest U.S. Crypto Company, Asserts Its Power in Washington
item.description: The top executive of the crypto exchange Coinbase scuttled a planned Senate committee vote on a major cryptocurrency bill after voicing his concerns, a sign of the company’s clout.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: A planned vote on a cryptocurrency bill on Thursday was canceled after Brian Armstrong, Coinbase’s chief executive, objected to the measure in a social media post on Wednesday evening.

item.title: Earnings Fall Short at Bank of America, Citi, JPMorgan and Wells Fargo
item.description: This week, Bank of America, Citi, JPMorgan and Wells Fargo released fraught earnings reports as President Trump’s threatened cap on credit card rates loomed large.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.media:description: Big bank stocks are up strongly over the past 12 months, even after the recent stumble.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Restricts Ability to Create Explicit Images With Grok
item.description: Bowing to pressure, the company said it would restrict X users from generating explicit images of real people in jurisdictions where such content is illegal.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prompt page for Grok, the artificial intelligence chatbot made by Elon Musk’s xAI.

item.title: Coinbase and the Crypto Revolt Against a Crypto Bill
item.description: Legislation to establish a regulatory framework for digital tokens has been thrown into turmoil — by one of its biggest champions.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: A closely watched crypto measure has run into opposition from one of the industry’s most powerful executives: Brian Armstrong of Coinbase.

item.title: Trump Vows to Make Venezuela Rich. It Will Take More Than U.S. Cash.
item.description: History suggests that the price of oil and a wider distribution of wealth are as important as foreign investment.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue in Caracas, Venezuela. While most oil-dependent countries are vulnerable to booms and busts, Venezuela has challenges even by those standards.

item.title: Leading Prediction Firms Share a Commonality: Donald Trump Jr.
item.description: Traders in companies with ties to the president’s eldest son can bet on the outcome of events the president affects.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. is both an investor in and an unpaid adviser to Polymarket, and a paid adviser to Kalshi, the two biggest prediction markets.

item.title: Boeing Knew About Flaws in UPS Plane That Crashed in Louisville, N.T.S.B. Says
item.description: In a report Wednesday, the National Transportation Safety Board said fractures that appeared to have led the left engine to separate from the plane’s wing had occurred at least four other times.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: A drone view of the crash site next to a runway at the Muhammad Ali International Airport, after the crash of a UPS cargo plane in Louisville, Ky., last year.
